Trait.Label: Packet Type
Trait.Name: PacketTypeCB
Trait.Hint: Pick your packet type to control the outbound packet types. For details about each type, see the PingPlotter manual on the web.

Trait.Label: Time to Wait for ping replies
Trait.Hint: The amount of time given a packet to return.  If not returned in this time, it's considered "lost".  The default value for this is 3000ms (3 seconds)

Trait.Label: Packet send delay
Trait.Hint:
The amount of time to wait between sending out each packet in a trace. This should be smaller for fast internet connections and bigger for slow ones. 
40 or higher works well (25 packets per second) on most connections.  Going too low can show artificial latency problems.

Trait.Label: Packet size
Trait.Hint: The IP size of the packet, including all IP headers. The default for ICMP packets is 56 bytes. For TCP packets, it's 40 bytes.

Trait.Label: Allow packet fragmentation?
Trait.Hint:
When checked, large packets (exceeding MTU size) can be split across multiple network packets. 
When cleared, only packets up to the MTU size will get a response (this can help troubleshoot MTU problems). 
This defaults to *ON*.

Trait.Label: Default (Packet #+Program Name/Version)
Trait.Hint: The default option is to fill the packet "Cargo" (non-critical packet space) with the packet number, then the Program Name + Version.

Enter a string value.  Can use these "escape" codes: 
 \xFF (where FF = a hex value)
 \255 (where 255 is an decimal value from 000 to 255)
 \r or \n for CR or LF
 \SAMPLENUM for text value of the current sample number (or SAMPLENUM_BIN for 4 byte binary version of same)
 \SEQNUM for TCP/IP sequence number (or SEQNUM_BIN for the 2 byte binary representation of that)
 \HOPNUM for the hop number of that packet, or HOPNUM_BIN for the 1 byte hop number.
